snippet: If the country confronts a new cash crunch in coming years, as many expect, it will not be able to use strong-arm tactics to force losses on its bondholders.
abstract: News analysis; Greek government was able to legally strong-arm most of its private bondholders into accepting a debt reduction deal, but the tactic is unlikely to succeed again in the future as the country confronts a fresh cash crunch; bulk of Greece's $341 billion debt is now held by the International Monetary Fund, European Central Bank and individual European nations, formidable groups that Greece would be hard-pressed to intimidate.
lead_paragraph: If the country confronts a new cash crunch in coming years, as many expect, it will not be able to use strong-arm tactics to force losses on its bondholders.

headline.main: Next Time, Greece May Need New Tactics
headline.print_headline: Bond Deal Narrows Options For Greece
